sentence1: Once upon a time a man named Hu-Wu-Bau, who lived near the Great Mountain, went walking there one day.
sentence2: And there, under a tree, he met a messenger in a red robe who called out to him: "The Lord of the Great Mountain would like to see you!"

sentence1: And there, under a tree, he met a messenger in a red robe who called out to him: "The Lord of the Great Mountain would like to see you!"
sentence2: The man was much frightened, but dared offer no objection.

sentence1: The man was much frightened, but dared offer no objection.
sentence2: The messenger bade him shut his eyes, and when he was allowed to open them again after a short time, he found himself standing before a lofty palace.

sentence1: The messenger bade him shut his eyes, and when he was allowed to open them again after a short time, he found himself standing before a lofty palace.
sentence2: He entered it to see the god.

sentence1: He entered it to see the god.
sentence2: The latter had a meal prepared for him and said: "I only sent for you to-day because I had heard you intended traveling to the West.

sentence1: The latter had a meal prepared for him and said: "I only sent for you to-day because I had heard you intended traveling to the West.
sentence2: And in that case I should like to give you a letter to take to my daughter."

sentence1: And in that case I should like to give you a letter to take to my daughter."
sentence2: asked the man.

sentence1: asked the man.
sentence2: When you reach the middle of the Yellow River, beat against the side of the ship and call out: 'Greencoat!'

sentence1: When you reach the middle of the Yellow River, beat against the side of the ship and call out: 'Greencoat!'
sentence2: Then some one will appear and take the letter from you."

sentence1: Then some one will appear and take the letter from you."
sentence2: And with these words he handed Hu-Wu-Bau the letter, and he was taken back again to the upper world.

sentence1: And with these words he handed Hu-Wu-Bau the letter, and he was taken back again to the upper world.
sentence2: When he came to the Yellow River on his journey, he did what the Lord of the Great Mountain had told him, and cried: "Greencoat!"

sentence1: When he came to the Yellow River on his journey, he did what the Lord of the Great Mountain had told him, and cried: "Greencoat!"
sentence2: And sure enough, a girl in green garments rose from the water, took him by the hand and told him to close his eyes.

sentence1: And sure enough, a girl in green garments rose from the water, took him by the hand and told him to close his eyes.
sentence2: Then she led him into the palace of the river-god and he delivered the letter.

sentence1: Then she led him into the palace of the river-god and he delivered the letter.
sentence2: The river-god entertained him splendidly, and thanked him as best he knew how.

sentence1: The river-god entertained him splendidly, and thanked him as best he knew how.
sentence2: At parting he said: "I am grateful that you have made this long journey to see me.

sentence1: At parting he said: "I am grateful that you have made this long journey to see me.
sentence2: I have nothing to give you, however, save this pair of green silk shoes.

sentence1: I have nothing to give you, however, save this pair of green silk shoes.
sentence2: While you are wearing them you can keep on walking as long as you like and never grow weary.

sentence1: While you are wearing them you can keep on walking as long as you like and never grow weary.
sentence2: And they will give you the second sight, so that you will be able to see the spirits and gods."

sentence1: And they will give you the second sight, so that you will be able to see the spirits and gods."
sentence2: The man thanked him for the gift and returned to his ship.

sentence1: The man thanked him for the gift and returned to his ship.
sentence2: When he reached the Great Mountain, he thought it would be fit and proper to report to the god.

sentence1: When he reached the Great Mountain, he thought it would be fit and proper to report to the god.
sentence2: So he once more knocked against the tree and gave his name.

sentence1: So he once more knocked against the tree and gave his name.
sentence2: In a moment the red-clad messenger appeared and led him to the Lord of the Mountain.

sentence1: In a moment the red-clad messenger appeared and led him to the Lord of the Mountain.
sentence2: So he reported that he had delivered the letter to the river-god, and how all things were there, and the Lord of the Mountain thanked him.

sentence1: So he reported that he had delivered the letter to the river-god, and how all things were there, and the Lord of the Mountain thanked him.
sentence2: During the meal which the god had prepared for him, he withdrew for a few moments to a quiet spot.

sentence1: During the meal which the god had prepared for him, he withdrew for a few moments to a quiet spot.
sentence2: Suddenly he saw his deceased father, bound and loaded with chains, who together with several hundred other criminals, was doing menial labor.

sentence1: Suddenly he saw his deceased father, bound and loaded with chains, who together with several hundred other criminals, was doing menial labor.
sentence2: Moved to tears, he asked: "O my father, why are you here?"

sentence1: Moved to tears, he asked: "O my father, why are you here?"
sentence2: His father replied: "During my life on earth I happened to tread on bread, hence I was condemned to hard labor at this spot.

sentence1: His father replied: "During my life on earth I happened to tread on bread, hence I was condemned to hard labor at this spot.
sentence2: I have passed two years in this manner, yet their bitterness has been unspeakable.

sentence1: I have passed two years in this manner, yet their bitterness has been unspeakable.
sentence2: Since you are acquainted with the Lord of the Mountain, you might plead for me, and beg him to excuse me from this task and make me the field-god in our village."

sentence1: Since you are acquainted with the Lord of the Mountain, you might plead for me, and beg him to excuse me from this task and make me the field-god in our village."
sentence2: His son promised to do so, and went back and pleaded with the Lord of the Mountain as he had agreed.

sentence1: His son promised to do so, and went back and pleaded with the Lord of the Mountain as he had agreed.
sentence2: The latter seemed inclined to listen to his prayer, yet said warningly: "The quick and the dead tread different paths.

sentence1: The latter seemed inclined to listen to his prayer, yet said warningly: "The quick and the dead tread different paths.
sentence2: It is not well for the dead and the living to abide near one another permanently."

sentence1: It is not well for the dead and the living to abide near one another permanently."
sentence2: Yet, in about a year's time nearly all his children had died.

sentence1: Yet, in about a year's time nearly all his children had died.

sentence1: He beat on the tree;
sentence2: the red-coat came and led him into the palace.

sentence1: the red-coat came and led him into the palace.
sentence2: There he told of his misfortune and begged the god to protect him.

sentence1: There he told of his misfortune and begged the god to protect him.
sentence2: The Lord of the Mountain smiled: "Did I not tell you in the start that the quick and the dead tread different paths, and that it is not well if they abide near each other permanently?

sentence1: The Lord of the Mountain smiled: "Did I not tell you in the start that the quick and the dead tread different paths, and that it is not well if they abide near each other permanently?
sentence2: Now you see what has happened!"

sentence1: Now you see what has happened!"
sentence2: Yet he sent his messenger to fetch the man's father.

sentence1: Yet he sent his messenger to fetch the man's father.
sentence2: The father came and the god spake to him as follows: "I forgave you your offense and sent you back to your home as a field-god.

sentence1: The father came and the god spake to him as follows: "I forgave you your offense and sent you back to your home as a field-god.
sentence2: It was your duty to bring happiness to your family.

sentence1: It was your duty to bring happiness to your family.
sentence2: And the father said: "I had been away from home so long that I was overjoyed to return.

sentence1: And the father said: "I had been away from home so long that I was overjoyed to return.
sentence2: Besides I had meat and drink in overflowing measure.

sentence1: Besides I had meat and drink in overflowing measure.
sentence2: So I thought of my little grand-children and called them to me."

sentence1: So I thought of my little grand-children and called them to me."
sentence2: Then the Lord of the Great Mountain appointed another field-god for that village, and also gave the father another place.

sentence1: Then the Lord of the Great Mountain appointed another field-god for that village, and also gave the father another place.
sentence2: And from that time no further misfortune happened to the family of Hu-Wu-Bau.
